Posts.Title: Liver Biopsy blainejennifer blainejennifer

Posts.Content: blainejennifer wrote: I've got the one DS, and he is off to college. Four. Hours. Away. We are - perhaps - too fond of each other, as he homeschooled for the last two years of high school, so I've seen a lot of him. I'm sure he's going to have a grand time in college. He's been chomping on the bit for at least a year now. "But what about me?", she whined. Before Stage 4, I had planned to get a job when he hit high school (ha!), so that by the time college rolled around I would be very involved in my next "act", and wouldn't droop too much when the nest emptied. Life is different now. I hope I see him graduate. I hope my health issues don't derail him. I also don't see how I could maintain a job outside the home, given chemo fatigue and all that. How have you guys managed this transition? I want him to thrive, without getting in his way. As much as I wanted him to go to college close by, I think the distance will be good for him. I see the anxiety on his face when I talk about cancer. He's a big fan of FaceTime and Skype, but I am yearning for the day he tells me that he's ending a call because he's got plans with his mates. He should be creating his own, unique life. Come September, I fear I will be blubbing for days. DH asked what my plans were for filling my time, come Fall. I grinched at him, then started crying. See what I mean? Heavy sigh and shoulder shrug. Cancer sucks. ER/PR+, HER2-, Grade 3. Stage 4, July 2012. Posts.Content: blainejennifer wrote: I'm doing weekly Taxol, and yesterday (3 days after chemo), I woke up with a funny numb/tingly feeling in my left hand that felt like the hand was asleep. I kept waiting for the hand to "wake up" and it didn't for most of the day. This morning, it's OK. Is that neuropathy, or did I just sleep on it wrong? I've never had neuropathy before. I take Gabapentin (3 capsules) daily to prevent neuropathy. Are there other interventions that you guys like? If this is neuropathy, should I be happy the hand came back online, or should I worry that it won't, in the future? I'm a knitting fool, so hand stuff worries me. Posts.Content: blainejennifer wrote: And it looks like I have some improvement in my rib cage and spine. During the bone scan, my arms were closer into the field than they were last time, so a lesion showed up on the humerous that wasn't in the field before. And, for some reason, that has thrown me for a loop. My tumor markers are 40ish (from a high of 2,600 in June). MO says to continue with weekly Taxol for now, keep the TMs down, and keep the lesions healing. Heavy sigh. I guess I wanted him to wave his magic wand and tell me that all the lesions were healed, and that I could dance merrily off to some delightful antihormonal that would let me grow my hair back and have my old energy back. And I am again reminded that this is a marathon, not a sprint. So, ladies, I'm going to take some Ativan, fire up "Bramwell", Season 3, and cruise about online looking at sock yarn. Posts.Content: blainejennifer wrote: I'm five months in from a Stage 4 diagnosis. Bone only (so far, right?). Did Tamoxifen/Zometa for two months and watched my TMs rise to 2,600 from 800 at diagnosis. I've done three months of weekly Taxol, and my TMs are down to 300 as of two weeks ago. My Onc seems to be leaning towards riding the Taxol out till it doesn't work anymore. If I stay stable, he sees a future where we increase the intervals between infusions. Since I was diagnosed while on Arimidex, and failed Tamoxifen, I see his attachment to chemo. But, I do miss hair. It's so shallow and venal, but I miss people not staring at me, and I miss strangers answering questions straight away without have that small pause that means they are thinking "What is up with her?" Has anybody out there done well on the stronger anti-hormonals after failing Tamoxifen and Arimidex? I'm thinking about asking him for a trial of Faslodex and Arimidex. Is anyone doing that with good results? Thanks. ER/PR+, HER2-, Grade 3. Stage 4, July 2012. Posts.Content: blainejennifer wrote: I was hanging with my favorite TN today, and we got to talking about how we breast fed our kids (singular for me, plural for her), and how we felt just the tiniest bit gypped by getting breast cancer after doing the "right thing". Then she asked me if I had a "good" boob when breastfeeding. I did. Old rightie could be counted on to let down first and keep going longer. Then she said that she got cancer in her best boob. So did I. So, how many of you had the same thing happen - cancer presenting first in the breast with the best dairy function? We are hoping that it can be a bit of lore to help women decide when to worry about lumps and bumps. If they are on your "good" side, perhaps we'll know to dial the doctor faster. Take care, Jennifer ER/PR+, HER2-, Grade 3. Stage 4, July 2012. Posts.Title: Long Term Management blainejennifer rkt

Posts.Content: blainejennifer wrote: I have a friend who had been dealing with Stage 4 prostate cancer, and he was doing well. But, he died two days ago. He had renal failure from chemotherapy. He was a very private man, and didn't alert his medical team that he was feeling poorly, as 7 weeks ago he "graduated" from chemo and was sent home and told to come in in three months time to check on his remission. Here's a link to read up on chemotherapy induced renal failure: http://news.cancerconnect.com/kidney-damage/ Renal failure can be addressed if caught early enough. My friend didn't let anyone know until he had advanced kidney failure. His best friend thought he sounded a bit confused during a phone call, so she took him to the oncologist, where he had a seizure. They sent him straight to the hospital (next door, luckily), but it was a losing battle. Damnit all. He was in remission. He had time left. So, read the article and familiarize yourself with the symptoms of renal failure. Really, any time you feel sick for longer than three days, check in with your medical support team. They want to know. He would like to know that he was helping us gain wisdom. That's how he rolled. ER/PR+, HER2-, Grade 3. Stage 4, July 2012. Posts.Content: blainejennifer wrote: Our fallen sisters, Reesie, ma111, LouiseBogle, Kentuckymom and all the other women who have so bravely fought this disease, supported and encouraged our community. Thanks to them, and all the people who have given their lives to breast cancer, there is more knowledge for us. Each day we live on contributes to the medical information that will provide the key to - one day - figuring out this cancer, and others. We have a forum for commemorating loved ones, but would anyone be in favor of making it more of a memorial wall with information about each person? I would like to read about these ladies, and their lives. They continue to inspire, even after death. Each person could have a thread, and we could post our memories of them. When I first joined the Stage 4 club, the angel postings scared me. Now, they inspire.  ER/PR+, HER2-, Grade 3. Stage 4, July 2012. Posts.Title: Mourning, Fear and Resolve blainejennifer Leah_S

Posts.Content: blainejennifer wrote: DH bit his tongue on a business trip, and it felt numb and funny the next day, so he went to the ER, and the second he said "My face feels numb", they send him off to a full neurologic examination. What they did find was a slightly enlarged pituitary, so they told him to get the images reviewed at home. Before the images can be viewed though, he's got to take an array of blood tests to look for any hormonal abnormalities (pituitary, ya know). At the ER, he had a low RBC, low WBC, low platelets and high MCV. They thought it was because he had just passed a small kidney stone. But, when he retook the blood tests here, three weeks later, the values didn't get any better. In fact, they were slightly worse. His PCP is "concerned". So now we get to go to the hematologist/oncologist together. This is not my idea of great spousal togetherness. He's had no symptoms. Maybe a little fatigue, because he has to deal with me, right? He's slim, never drinks, has eaten "paleo" for 17 years now, and walks several miles a day. He's the guy who always takes the stairs, and thinks that a bit of dark chocolate is a wild treat. We have a bright, quirky 16 year old boy who - thanks to my health problems - had real trouble with anxiety last year. This year has started well for him, but, I worry. I'm trying to google with discrimination. All the signs are pointing to a bone marrow problem. Let the silent screaming begin. You parents know what I mean. I have a terminal disease. I mean, I'm going to be around for a bit more, but I'm not planning anything for my 80th birthday. DH needs to be the parent that lives. Our kid is not super-resilient. Knowing DH would be around has been a real comfort. Plus, I'm crazy in love with the man. We've been together 34 years. I don't really know why I'm writing this. Maybe because if I don't tell someone, I'm going to spend days sobbing. DH is on a business trip that couldn't be postponed. It's just me and DS. No family here. And, I'm so tired of being a burden to my friends with all the health crud. They have their own lives, and might begin to have compassion fatigue. Can I just say that as a life lesson, i wouldn't start a family so far away from kin if I had to do it again. I mean, if you like your family, that is. I do. Off to go take another Ativan, smile brightly for my son, and clean nervously. ER/PR+, HER2-, Grade 3. Stage 4, July 2012. Posts.Content: blainejennifer wrote: Thursday was chemo day - I'm doing weekly taxol. So, I'm waiting for chemo, after having the finger stick*, and one of the waiting patients says, "Hey you were here a month ago. Didn't you have more hair?" I did. I'm really rocking the one month old infant look now. She keeps talking, and it's clear that she's a Loud Talker. That's cool. The center has patients stacked liked cordwood, and things are running a bit slow. I don't mind talking to pass the time. She's talking, I'm listening, and then she makes a comment to the effect that if she were stage 4, she'd just shoot herself. At that point in the conversation, I'm willing to let her. What I need are clever rejoinders for when people freak out about stage 4. This about the third time it's happened to me, and I'm always caught at a loss. I mean, yes, stage 4 sucks, but I'm right in front of them, having a life. I could give the fear back: "Hey, you could be stage 4 now, and not even know it." But, that's mean. Or, I could discount it: "Oh, it's not so bad. I get to watch a lot of TV." That's my guilty secret; I do watch a massive amount of TV (shout out to Marybe and the TV thread). Snappy rejoinders please. I could educate and amuse at the same time! Maybe we could do a whole infusion center protocol thread. Like, "Please don't blare your television set. Use the supplied headphones." Or, "You'll notice we have one bathroom that doesn't have a door threshhold so that IV poles can come in and out easily. Do not usurp this bathroom, fixing your wig, while there's a large lady waiting outside, trying not to wet herself." Feeling a bit tired and crabby. Does it show? Jennifer *BTW: I've never failed the counts yets. Do you think I could ask to skip the stick and have them take it from my line when they access the port? Do you guys have a finger stick? For my initial chemo, they always took it from the line, then they'd keep the line open with a saline drip till the counts came back. ER/PR+, HER2-, Grade 3. Stage 4, July 2012. Posts.Title: Infusion Center Moments blainejennifer Fitztwins

Posts.Content: blainejennifer wrote: Thursday was chemo day - I'm doing weekly taxol. So, I'm waiting for chemo, after having the finger stick*, and one of the waiting patients says, "Hey you were here a month ago. Didn't you have more hair?" I did. I'm really rocking the one month old infant look now. She keeps talking, and it's clear that she's a Loud Talker. That's cool. The center has patients stacked liked cordwood, and things are running a bit slow. I don't mind talking to pass the time. She's talking, I'm listening, and then she makes a comment to the effect that if she were stage 4, she'd just shoot herself. At that point in the conversation, I'm willing to let her. What I need are clever rejoinders for when people freak out about stage 4. This about the third time it's happened to me, and I'm always caught at a loss. I mean, yes, stage 4 sucks, but I'm right in front of them, having a life. I could give the fear back: "Hey, you could be stage 4 now, and not even know it." But, that's mean. Or, I could discount it: "Oh, it's not so bad. I get to watch a lot of TV." That's my guilty secret; I do watch a massive amount of TV (shout out to Marybe and the TV thread). Snappy rejoinders please. I could educate and amuse at the same time! Maybe we could do a whole infusion center protocol thread. Like, "Please don't blare your television set. Use the supplied headphones." Or, "You'll notice we have one bathroom that doesn't have a door threshhold so that IV poles can come in and out easily. Do not usurp this bathroom, fixing your wig, while there's a large lady waiting outside, trying not to wet herself." Feeling a bit tired and crabby. Does it show? Jennifer *BTW: I've never failed the counts yets. Do you think I could ask to skip the stick and have them take it from my line when they access the port? Do you guys have a finger stick? For my initial chemo, they always took it from the line, then they'd keep the line open with a saline drip till the counts came back. ER/PR+, HER2-, Grade 3. Stage 4, July 2012. Posts.Content: blainejennifer wrote: I was diagnosed 6 years ago with ER/PR+, HER - Grade 3, Stage 2b (5cm mass, 4 hot nodes). Did the mastectomy, chemo and radiation. Side note: I found the lump originally, but because I was younger at the time (44), both mammography and sonography didn't find anything, so the radiologist said there was "nothing there", and off I went on my merry way. Then my nipple started inverting, blah blah blah. Six months later, I had breast cancer. My breast tissue was so dense, the original round of imaging didn't reveal anything. I'm not bitter, but I am quite firm about people getting tissue biopsies for anything suspicious now.  My son (12) gave me whooping cough for Christmas. I spent about two months coughing so hard, I'd have to sit down or lie down to ride the coughs out. Then my right side (cancer side) started hurting badly. So, I went to see my GP, who ordered a blood panel. I asked her to throw in the CA 27-29, as it had been a year since my last one (normal). A great frenzy ensued, as my CA 27-29 values were 750, and a week later 850!! Off to the CAT and PET scans, which showed two sclerotic lesions on one rib, and one vertebrae. The radiologist thought they were to be expected from the cough. My oncologist knew about the tumor markers though, and thinks that they are metastasis.  I've done my first Zometa (I had all the side effects, plus some from other ladies it felt like), and was switched from Arimidex to Tamoxifen. I'm going in next week for labs and more Zometa. Good times.I have read that Tamoxifen might be a better choice for obese ladies, and even though I have recently lost 60 pounds on Atkins, I do have a good 40 to go.  My ribs seem to be taking their own sweet time healing up. I doesn't help that I have a year old dog who yanks my arm off when she sees a bird (we are working on that), and I decided to fight the Lily-of-the-Valley in the garden.   I'm getting used to the idea of Stage 4, thanks to Ativan. I am clinging to the faint hope that the fractured rib threw off the tumor markers. I have heard anecdotal reference to broken bones elevating the numbers, but have read no reliable reference. Is that just a crazy notion, or have you guys heard ot it?  This forum rocks, by the way. I think my head would have exploded without it. Thanks!   ER/PR+, HER2-, Grade 3. Stage 4, July 2012. Posts.Title: Whooping Cough, Rib Fractures, and Stage 4 blainejennifer reesie

Posts.Content: blainejennifer wrote: I'm obese. At 5'6", I weigh 215 pounds. In the past two years I've lost 60 pounds and I have more to go. No medical professional has ever discussed my weight with me! Every time my husband sees his PCP, he gets his tummy prodded and is told to lose ten pounds.  I'm trying to figure out why. Maybe they think that at that level of overweight, surely I know, and that further discussion would be embarassing to me. I also owned up to it. But, I could have used some discussion and support. Losing weight is hard, and we - the obese - need to hear the message from our medical team. Especially given my hormone positive pathology. I'm a little bitter. I wish my oncologist had looked me straight in the eye and said that if I didnt lose the weight, I was looking at metastasis down the road. I'd have started sooner and lost weight faster (I think, I hope). Coulda, woulda, shoulda, right? So, the message to my fluffy crowd is that obesity is Not Good for the hormone positive set. Adipose tissue produces estradial - the less you have, the better. Also, it interferes with insulin signaling pathways, leading to higher blood sugar levels, which are also contraindicated for breast cancer patients. Getting breast cancer is multifactorial. Obesity alone won't "give" you cancer, so I'm not pointing the finger and blaming anyone for being the instigator of their own disease. But, reducing body mass is an important tool in managing this #$#@%# disease, and I wish my doctors had been a little more strident in making sure that information got through to me. What has your experience been with this? Did your doctors discuss weight? Were you educated, or just treated? ER/PR+, HER2-, Grade 3. Stage 4, July 2012. Posts.Title: Doctors and Obesity blainejennifer justjudie

Posts.Content: blainejennifer wrote: I just finished reading "The Death of Cancer" by Vincent DeVIta, who has spent his medical career in and around chemotherapy, in various big-time places (NCI, Yale), so I was very interested in what he had to say. It's a good read, as he had an auxiliary author. Anyway, in the concluding chapters, he makes a case for big blast chemo as an approach to metastatic cancer. It seems that palliative chemo only teaches the cancer cells how to survive the chemotherapeutic agent eventually, and it is not an avenue to a cure. He also points out that fear of toxic side effects kept chemotherapy from being fully utilized in the 1960's and 1970's. This is a synopsis, of course. It seems that it is his belief that metastatic patients should have a go with chemotherapeutic agents that they have not been exposed to. When I was diagnosed with Stage 4, I asked my Onc why I wouldn't have a course of chemo like I had when I was early stage, and I was waved off with talk of it not being effective, etc. However, I have looked through the data, and find no clinical evidence of that belief. I have a dubious nature, I also believe that I didn't have a shot at a full early stage cure because of the outdated belief that fat ladies shouldn't be given the full body weight dosage of chemo because it would be too toxic. That methodology has been disproved. Actual fact: I begged my original Onc for two more rounds of Taxol during my early stage treatment. I was tolerating it very well, and I wanted to grind any remaining cancer cells into the dust. I was, of course, not accommodated. I'm sure she didn't want me coming back, years later with leukemia as a result, but - in hind sight - maybe I wouldn't be Stage 4 now. So, are we not being offered a chance at real remission because of an idea, or because of actual evidence? ER/PR+, HER2-, Grade 3. Stage 4, July 2012. Posts.Title: Zometa Bitchiness blainejennifer

Posts.Content: blainejennifer wrote: Up until three weeks ago, my biggest problem were some extensive bone mets in the thoracic spine area. Got those zapped, 15 sessions, and it seems to have been helping. Then, two weeks ago, some of my liver values popped up, AST and ALT. So, I am gently slid, burrito style, into the PET/CT scan to see what is what. Progression is what that is. Diffuse progression, so there is no clearly defined target to aim for. Gulp. Due to some compulsive reading, I know this is scary. If your liver can't process chemo, the liver can fail trying. If I don't respond to Gemzar/Carboplatin, I'll start hearing words like "comfort care" and "hospice". I'm not crazy. I know that I won't last forever on treatment, but I need two more years to see my child graduate from college. I'm sure God is busily putting that in their calculations - "Oh, that's right. Jennifer needs two more years for her one kid. Perhaps I'll take it from this lady over here, the one in Yemen who has a three hour walk for treatment, if the clinic is open, that is." Luckily, the menfolk are out of the house. DS is back at college. DH is doing his thing in NYC. So, I can undulate around the house for a few days, crying to expunge the sorrow, and to get my mental fanny in gear. Does anyone have advice as to what the heck to do? I will be seeking a second opinion at Roswell Park. I've already got a berth there, from last year when I wanted a second opinion on some CAR T trials at the U of Virginia. BTW, that trial would be great for HER2+ patients. Not so much for HER2-. Trial identifier: NCT03272334. I've several other trials identified. I'm not the most popular girl at the party, as I am extensively pretreated, but the ones that could go, I'm putting in for. I am hoping that by tomorrow, my brain will have rebooted and I might be able to think again. Goals are: 1. Figure out what to beg for should the Gemzar/Carbo not do all that was planned. 2. Pull all strings available/Get second opinion arranged. 3. Arrange 30 minutes of vigorous pouting, then call it a day on that sort of thing. Frankly, I'd rather blast Sandi Patti, and make a joyful noise, etc. Golly. I have just run out of steam. Going to go to sleep now. Forgive any errors - I know there will be tons. I don't know what I'd do without y'all. Jennifer ER/PR+, HER2-, Grade 3. Stage 4, July 2012. Posts.Content: blainejennifer wrote: When I was in college, we used to play a game called "Shame". Yes, it involved drinking, but the point of the game was to state the most shameful thing about yourself you could think of. I won a round once with the fact that - while I was an English major - I had tried to read "Jane Eyre" but bogged down and hated it. I live in a house of men, so you know that I am the only one who cares about the state of the toilet and other such housekeepy things. And, to be honest, cleaning standards have devolved around here, so my inaugural entry into the Stage 4 Hall of Shame is . . . I can not recall (and I've tried) the last time I vacuumed upstairs. And, it is off-white carpeting that is getting more and more off-white. And, to be honest, the only time the floor downstairs gets cleaned is when my older dog poos on it. Then I'll clean the general area. Alright, who am I kidding? When no one is looking, Ill clean up the poo, but if it is not goopy, I'll not wet clean the area. Shaaaaaaaame. My Southern mother would rise up out of her grave and chide me. Is there anyone else who would like to play? Jennifer ER/PR+, HER2-, Grade 3. Stage 4, July 2012. Posts.Title: Housekeeping Hall of Shame blainejennifer mirryp

Posts.Content: blainejennifer wrote: Trigger Alert: The following is about poop. Possible TMI situation. Thanks to opiates and anti-nausea meds, I have turned into my granny, and spend my mornings trying to placate the poop gods. I'm eating 15 prunes daily, taking stool softeners (6!) and four senna tablets, in addition to seeking out whole grains and fiber-iffic fruits and vegetables. Bran and coffee in the morning, and walking at least a mile a day. Who knew constipation could be so tedious? And, how much it makes you need to pee? I figure there's a poo baby pressing on my bladder. So, how close to the sun can I dance with the senna tablets? I have a fear of going too far in the other direction, and spending the day in the restroom. ER/PR+, HER2-, Grade 3. Stage 4, July 2012. Posts.Title: All About Defecation blainejennifer LindaE54

Posts.Content: blainejennifer wrote: I want to start preparing for the end. It is very clear that my darling family thinks I am just going to keep on ticking, but, as I am nearing my 5th year of treatment, and have run through the anti-hormonals, I think I'm in the middle. In your experience, how does it go? Do we fail all the possible therapies, then have palliative care until our bodies stop? As much as I like the idea of plenty of warning, for my family's sake, how do our brains fare under the daily knowledge that death is near? I imagine towards the end, our bodies start feeling like places we should leave. Discomfort, pain, and all that. I try to remember that there was a world before I was born, and I do not resent that world. Therefore, I should have no strong opinion about being dead. But, I surely do now. Birth, death, it's all a process. I feel like a toddler who has been told to go to bed, when all the other kids are still at the party. I'm tired and all, but look - those kids are having so much fun. When my Dad died of cancer, they told him that he would have about three months before he started failing, after they stopped treatment. In two weeks, he was dead. He refused to eat and drink, and took himself out. My Mom fought for two years with her cancer, and died of C-Diff in the hospital. In both those cases, they weren't ready. They hadn't talked about death, or even made financial arrangements. So, wise ladies, what is the easiest way to pull this off, so that my family feels the least stress? I've got the will done. They know I want a "do" at the local dog park. Just pass around some cookies that aren't bad for the dogs, and hurl my ashes someplace the dogs won't roll in. I've started minimizing possessions, so they won't have to plow through years of old make-up. I plan on being here for as long as possible. It seems like this sort of thing is best done bit-by-bit, so as not to blub all the time. What is the nicest way of reminding my son that I will not be here sooner, rather than later, without devastating him? Whenever he thinks I am on his back, I remind him that I have to get it all in now, so I am Queen of the Concentrated Nag. He's having trouble at school, with depression, and the feeling that High School is a crock, and has no relation to the real world. He's academically bright, but the busywork makes him nuts. So, we are homeschooling, starting Monday. That's a different conversation, but I am really looking forward to all that time spent with him. Selfish Mommy. He'll be getting a part-time job for social interaction, doing some internships, and taking two classes at the local college, in addition to regular old homeschooling. Wow, I'm waffling all over the place today. So sorry. Started Halaven on Tuesday, and just took some pain meds before writing this. Short Summary: Teach me, wise ladies, how to die with style and ease, so that I don't trash my family on the way out. Jennifer ER/PR+, HER2-, Grade 3. Stage 4, July 2012. Currently on Gemzar/Carboplatin Dx 5/2006, IDC, 4cm, Stage IIB, Grade 3, 4/12 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2- Dx 3/2012, IDC, Stage IV, 4/12 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2- Chemotherapy 6/28/2012 Taxol (paclitaxel) Hormonal Therapy 6/5/2013 Faslodex (fulvestrant) Chemotherapy 7/1/2014 Xeloda (capecitabine) Hormonal Therapy 8/14/2015 Femara (letrozole) Chemotherapy 1/31/2016 Halaven (eribulin) Chemotherapy 8/31/2016 CMF Chemotherapy 11/1/2016 Halaven (eribulin) Chemotherapy Carboplatin (Paraplatin), Gemzar (gemcitabine) Log in to post a reply

Posts.Title: Completely Scary Topic: How Do We Die? blainejennifer magdalene51

Posts.Content: blainejennifer wrote: I was going to put this in the liver mets thread, but it is more than that. In the past week, my Mom died. She was 99 and went peacefully, but my sister didn't let me know because she was angry at my brothers. It is a long complex story, but the shortest version is that she was my Mom's caregiver and guardian, and my brothers have not helped at all. I used to before the Stage 4 diagnosis, but traveling got difficult, and only made it out there twice in the past five years. But, I stayed in touch. Mom had dementia, for twenty years, so my sister did have a big job. Mom had enough money, but it's still hard. However you slice it, my Mom was dying, and I didn't know till three days after she passed. This morning, my son informs me that he is really tanking his first semester at college. He is smart, but has wicked ADHD. By really tanking, I mean to say that he is passing one class. Doing very well in it, but Come On. Alrightee - we knew he'd be changing his major, but I'm still not getting a full story out of him as to what - exactly - is the problem. Absences? Late work? It's not the end of the world. He is healthy, loves the campus (maybe too much, right?), and we are getting some supports in place for next semester. But, his scholarship is gone, and that is going to be an issue. Wait - there's more. For the first time in six years of treatment, I had to go to the ER last Friday because my intestines stopped working. I'd had massive over-production, from a constipation correction, and it just wouldn't stop, even when it ran out of food ammunition. Then it felt like my insides were blown up and hot, with sharp pains. This isn't normal, so off to the ER I head. They were marvelous, and I even got my favorite infusion nurse to jump over and access my port for the CAT scan and lab work. They diagnose ulcerative colitis, and put me on an antibiotic regimen. I am improving, slowly. Today, I'm supposed to get chemo (Doxil, 8th round), but my MO calls to say that there is significant liver progression based on the ER's CAT scan, but he's away dealing with his mother-in-law and won't be back in the office till Friday. We will talk options then. He was comforting, and said that there were options. But, let's get real. I've been on Arimidex, Tamoxifen, Taxol, Faslodex, Letrozole/Ibrance, Xeloda, Halaven, CMF and Doxil. I am using up options. He seemed more upset about my colitis, so now I'm thinking it's got something to do with my liver, and not my Mother or Son - I do tend to take my emotions out on my innards. Here I am now, trying to keep moving forward, but the will is gone. If I died today, my son could just bundle the grief into his first semester's woes, and be ready to get at it come mid-January. I know I'm going to kick him in the fanny in the future, what with dying and all, and I hate that. My spouse would recover, and he wouldn't have to change jobs to keep from traveling so much. My brothers could pretend to grieve, and I'd go into the same plot as my Mom. How do you keep going? So many of you have been pummeled by life, and you don't surrender. For the first time in my life, I wish I had religious faith. Yes, I have taken some Ativan. I will be seeking counseling, if for nothing else than learning how to help my kid make it into adulthood. My poor husband has to deal with all this, and show up happy and productive at work. He is amazing. ER/PR+, HER2-, Grade 3. Stage 4, July 2012. Posts.Content: blainejennifer wrote: Had my recent scan results today, and all my other bone mets are stable or retreating, except for one pesky area on my hip. So, off to radiation whack-a-mole. I'm actually looking forward to it, as MO thinks it will get more mileage out of my current Faslodex regimen, which I am enjoying as it is very kind. And, frankly, my hip has been achy, and it wakes me up at night. Have any of you out there squeezed the juice out of a protocol with this maneuver? Should I be agitating for a treatment change? One thing I will be asking MO tomorrow is if this is a good time to get a bone biopsy before radiation begins. I've had no biopsy for Stage 4, just imaging. I could also use radiation advice, pretty please. Thanks, Jennifer ER/PR+, HER2-, Grade 3. Stage 4, July 2012. Posts.Content: blainejennifer wrote: Up until three weeks ago, my biggest problem were some extensive bone mets in the thoracic spine area. Got those zapped, 15 sessions, and it seems to have been helping. Then, two weeks ago, some of my liver values popped up, AST and ALT. So, I am gently slid, burrito style, into the PET/CT scan to see what is what. Progression is what that is. Diffuse progression, so there is no clearly defined target to aim for. Gulp. Due to some compulsive reading, I know this is scary. If your liver can't process chemo, the liver can fail trying. If I don't respond to Gemzar/Carboplatin, I'll start hearing words like "comfort care" and "hospice". I'm not crazy. I know that I won't last forever on treatment, but I need two more years to see my child graduate from college. I'm sure God is busily putting that in their calculations - "Oh, that's right. Jennifer needs two more years for her one kid. Perhaps I'll take it from this lady over here, the one in Yemen who has a three hour walk for treatment, if the clinic is open, that is." Luckily, the menfolk are out of the house. DS is back at college. DH is doing his thing in NYC. So, I can undulate around the house for a few days, crying to expunge the sorrow, and to get my mental fanny in gear. Does anyone have advice as to what the heck to do? I will be seeking a second opinion at Roswell Park. I've already got a berth there, from last year when I wanted a second opinion on some CAR T trials at the U of Virginia. BTW, that trial would be great for HER2+ patients. Not so much for HER2-. Trial identifier: NCT03272334. I've several other trials identified. I'm not the most popular girl at the party, as I am extensively pretreated, but the ones that could go, I'm putting in for. I am hoping that by tomorrow, my brain will have rebooted and I might be able to think again. Goals are: 1. Figure out what to beg for should the Gemzar/Carbo not do all that was planned. 2. Pull all strings available/Get second opinion arranged. 3. Arrange 30 minutes of vigorous pouting, then call it a day on that sort of thing. Frankly, I'd rather blast Sandi Patti, and make a joyful noise, etc. Golly. I have just run out of steam. Going to go to sleep now. Forgive any errors - I know there will be tons. I don't know what I'd do without y'all. Jennifer ER/PR+, HER2-, Grade 3. Stage 4, July 2012. Posts.Content: blainejennifer wrote: My very loved FIL entered the hospital Saturday with double Pneumonia that just kinda snuck up on him. He's 86, and was in fabulous health and living independently. Soon after admit, his heart kicked up a bit, stabilized, but he'd already been put on a ventilator as he couldn't get his oxygen sats into the 90's. Then he got renal failure. That was Monday. As of today, his heart and lungs have recovered and are stable, but he is still in renal failure and still ventilated. He had made it very clear in his medical directive that he didn't want to persist under extraordinary medical care. He lost two wives to ALS (Cleveland area, Great Lakes cyanobacteria, whole other story), so he's well aware of what living compromised is like. His kids fear that he is sliding down the slippery slope from temporary ventilator support to the ventilator keeping him alive. Which he didn't want. And you know how it is in ICU. The hospitalist is encouraged that he recovered heart and lung function. The nephrologist is very dour. The infection specialist is worried about his continued low platelet count - that's why he can't be put on dialysis. What I'm asking for is some real world advise/experience on his recovery. If it is possible that he will recover with some quality of life, his kids are going to keep pushing. But, if it looks like he'll be intensely medicalized for the rest of his life, his kids realize that they are going to have to respect his clear medical directive for no extraordinary measures. Me personally? I so much want him to live - in whatever manner. I know it's selfish and venal, and doesn't take into account his desires. He's Very Catholic, and death would be a promotion for him. He truly believes he will see his siblings and his two loved wives in Heaven. As of this morning, he's stable, but no real renal function as of yet. We are all aware that if this persists, his body will pretty much make the decision for us. Sadly, Jennifer ER/PR+, HER2-, Grade 3. Stage 4, July 2012. Posts.Title: OT: Need Advice on FIL's Medical Condition blainejennifer Leah_S

Posts.Content: blainejennifer wrote: This is a stumper for me. I have two brothers, and I've tried to keep them in the loop about my treatment yada yada. When I was first diagnosed, the best part was that it brought my brothers and I closer. Previous to the dx, we had grown apart as they all live in Texas, and I don't. Up until this year, I visited them every year (weekly chemo clipped my wings). My little brother visits me once a year when a business trip brings him close, and my big brother has never really had the funds to go travelling. Now, I'm Stage 4, and after a small flurry of interest, my brothers have tapped out. Phone calls - nope. Emails - not so much. I call and email, but get crickets in return. They got together for Thanksgiving and didn't even call me. Jeez - I'm crying as I write this. They did the same thing to my Mom as she was dying, but they'd always had a problematic relationship with her. I wasn't expecting they'd treat me the same way. I know I should tell them how I feel, but I want to do it without blubbing. It's not like they ever paid a whole bunch of attention to me, but the Thanksgiving thing got me. How have you guys handled family? BTW, I've had one lovely friend through out treatment. She plays with me like I'm normal - love that! ER/PR+, HER2-, Grade 3. Stage 4, July 2012. Posts.Title: How to Deal with Uncommunicative Family blainejennifer LauraOntario

Posts.Content: blainejennifer wrote: I want to start preparing for the end. It is very clear that my darling family thinks I am just going to keep on ticking, but, as I am nearing my 5th year of treatment, and have run through the anti-hormonals, I think I'm in the middle. In your experience, how does it go? Do we fail all the possible therapies, then have palliative care until our bodies stop? As much as I like the idea of plenty of warning, for my family's sake, how do our brains fare under the daily knowledge that death is near? I imagine towards the end, our bodies start feeling like places we should leave. Discomfort, pain, and all that. I try to remember that there was a world before I was born, and I do not resent that world. Therefore, I should have no strong opinion about being dead. But, I surely do now. Birth, death, it's all a process. I feel like a toddler who has been told to go to bed, when all the other kids are still at the party. I'm tired and all, but look - those kids are having so much fun. When my Dad died of cancer, they told him that he would have about three months before he started failing, after they stopped treatment. In two weeks, he was dead. He refused to eat and drink, and took himself out. My Mom fought for two years with her cancer, and died of C-Diff in the hospital. In both those cases, they weren't ready. They hadn't talked about death, or even made financial arrangements. So, wise ladies, what is the easiest way to pull this off, so that my family feels the least stress? I've got the will done. They know I want a "do" at the local dog park. Just pass around some cookies that aren't bad for the dogs, and hurl my ashes someplace the dogs won't roll in. I've started minimizing possessions, so they won't have to plow through years of old make-up. I plan on being here for as long as possible. It seems like this sort of thing is best done bit-by-bit, so as not to blub all the time. What is the nicest way of reminding my son that I will not be here sooner, rather than later, without devastating him? Whenever he thinks I am on his back, I remind him that I have to get it all in now, so I am Queen of the Concentrated Nag. He's having trouble at school, with depression, and the feeling that High School is a crock, and has no relation to the real world. He's academically bright, but the busywork makes him nuts. So, we are homeschooling, starting Monday. That's a different conversation, but I am really looking forward to all that time spent with him. Selfish Mommy. He'll be getting a part-time job for social interaction, doing some internships, and taking two classes at the local college, in addition to regular old homeschooling. Wow, I'm waffling all over the place today. So sorry. Started Halaven on Tuesday, and just took some pain meds before writing this. Short Summary: Teach me, wise ladies, how to die with style and ease, so that I don't trash my family on the way out. Jennifer ER/PR+, HER2-, Grade 3. Stage 4, July 2012. Posts.Content: blainejennifer wrote: Saw my MO today because my left ankle was swollen. He sent me in for an ultrasound, and, yes, I do have a blood clot in my femoral vein/artery. I think. I just started hearing a lot of white noise. The big take-away is that I have a leg clot, and I'm going to have to inject myself with stuff to keep from having some rather ghastly problems. I am needle phobic. I just did it for the first time. It stings. Should it? Am I doing something wrong. Are there old hands at this in this forum who could talk me down? I don't think agonizing about it for an hour and sobbing while doing it is a sustainable model. I've stopped blubbing for now. In other news, progeny has returned home for summer break, and is so bummed about not being near their friends, that they have retired to their bedroom for what looks like some epic blues-style sulking. What a happy, happy household. Jennifer ER/PR+, HER2-, Grade 3. Stage 4, July 2012.
